grounding: We review our recent quantum stochastic model for spectroscopic lineshapes in the presence of a coevolving and nonstationary background population of excitations. Starting from a field theory description for interacting bosonic excitons, we derive a reduced model whereby optical excitons are coupled to an incoherent background via scattering as mediated by their screened Coulomb coupling. The Heisenberg equations of motion for the optical excitons are then driven by an auxiliary stochastic population variable, which we take to be the solution of an Ornstein–Uhlenbeck process. Here, we present an overview of the theoretical techniques we have developed as applied to predicting coherent nonlinear spectroscopic signals. We show how direct (Coulomb) and exchange coupling to the bath give rise to distinct spectral signatures and discuss mathematical limits on inverting spectral signatures to extract the background density of states.
generated_text: This study investigates the optical signatures of stochastic processes in many-body exciton scattering, focusing on excitation-induced dephasing and its impact on coherent nonlinear spectroscopy. We employ quantum stochastic calculus to model the complex interactions between excitons in semiconductor nanostructures, revealing how many-body effects influence quantum dynamics. Our theoretical framework combines advanced spectroscopic techniques with sophisticated mathematical tools to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of exciton-exciton interactions. We demonstrate that stochastic fluctuations in the local environment significantly affect the coherence and relaxation dynamics of excitons, leading to distinct spectral features in nonlinear optical measurements. These findings provide crucial insights into the fundamental nature of many-body phenomena in quantum systems and offer new avenues for interpreting and manipulating exciton dynamics in advanced optoelectronic devices.
